content.description:
Climbs easy cracks and chimneys between ledges on the west face's path of least resistance. Extremely chossy, and runout on easy ground... the cracks are protectable but if you slip on the layer of talus you are in for trouble. The route sort of ends at the notch, but you can continue unprotected to either summit.

Downclimb the east gully (much easier than it looks) or rap off a bush if that isn't to your liking. Make sure you have a follower to clean the gear cause it would be difficult to descend the way you came.
content.protection: A few small cams for the first two cracks. A #4 placed decently in the final chimney. Slings to extend pieces and a big cord/webbing to sling the horn at top for an anchor (the only reliable pro up there.)
content.location: Begin in between two bushes in a cramped chimney which may be the technical crux.

content.description: Slightly chossy, but not terrible rock with easy moves to the top.  A fun location right near the trail and parking lot.
content.location: On the southern face of Agathla Tower, right next to the Near Trail

content.description: The easiest route to the notch of Agathla Tower. Begin by the tree on the east side at the top of the scree fan. Scramble up a short pillar to a ledge, then up slippery easy terrain to the notch. You can climb further to the summit, but beware, it's basically unprotectable and you'll have to downclimb it. Choss wrangling at its simplest.
content.protection: Best soloed? A few cams if you want, and something to sling a big horn if belaying a follower.
content.location: Behind the tree on the east side.

content.description: Aesthetic movement but you won't notice because of the chossy rock, however, there's nothing too dangerous for your average vantage trad climber and might just round out a long day.
content.location: Obvious open book on the south side of Agathla tower
